questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of abdominal distention and twitching of her feet, which her mother noticed a week ago. The patient has also had a low-grade fever for 5 days. She has not had a bowel movement in 3 days. She was born at term and has been healthy since. She is at the 40th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 128/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Examination shows an irregular palpable mass that crosses the midline of the abdomen. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. There are erratic movements of the eyes. A 24-hour urine collection shows elevated homovanillic acid and vanillylmandelic acid levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hodgkin lymphoma typically manifests as cervical lymphadenopathy or a mediastinal mass in young adults or older individuals (bimodal age distribution). While it often causes fevers, other B symptoms such as night sweats or weight loss are absent in this patient. Also, a diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma would not explain this patient's abdominal mass, elevated urine catecholamine metabolites, or abnormal eye and foot movement.

B) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma is a tumor that usually arises on the adrenal medulla and manifests with episodic hypertension, headaches, and diaphoresis secondary to catecholamine release. The suprarenal mass is sometimes palpable and causes increased levels of urine catecholamine metabolites, both of which are seen here. However, pheochromocytomas generally do not occur in children unless there is a family history (e.g., multiple endocrine neoplasia), which makes this tumor less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the most common childhood cancer and usually manifests with fatigue, easy bruising, and unexplained weight loss. While it can also cause fevers, ALL would not explain this patient's abdominal mass, elevated urine catecholamine metabolites, or abnormal eye and foot movement, making it an unlikely cause of her symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Hepatoblastoma is a rare childhood tumor that may also manifest with a large, irregular abdominal mass in a young child. However, hepatoblastoma would not explain this child's abnormal eye and foot movements, and it would not cause an elevation in urine catecholamine metabolites.

E) INCORRECT:

Nephroblastoma (i.e., Wilms tumor) is a childhood tumor that may also manifest with hypertension, abdominal distention, and a large abdominal mass. However, in contrast to this patient's abdominal mass, nephroblastomas do not cross midline and tend to be smooth rather than irregular. Additionally, nephroblastoma would not explain the elevated catecholamine metabolite levels seen here, nor would it cause abnormal eye and foot movements.

F) CORRECT:

Neuroblastoma is a malignant neuroendocrine tumor that can manifest with abdominal distention, constipation and a palpable, irregular mass that crosses the midline. Further features include failure to thrive, hypertension, and fever, as well as opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome, which explains the patient's twitching feet and erratic eye movements. Although neuroblastomas can originate from any aggregation of sympathetic nervous tissue, > 60% arise in the abdomen, as seen in this patient. The characteristic diagnostic finding is elevated urine catecholamine metabolites (homovanillic and vanillylmandelic acid). Treatment is based upon the extent of disease, age at diagnosis, and the presence/absence of N-myc amplification, and usually involves a combination of chemotherapy and surgical excision.

G) INCORRECT:

Rhabdomyosarcoma is a rare tumor that usually develops in the head and neck region but can also occur in the genitourinary tract (25% of cases). Although a very large bladder tumor could explain this patient's abdominal mass and constipation, most rhabdomyosarcomas are not palpable and would not cause elevations in urine catecholamine metabolites.

H) INCORRECT:

Mesoblastic nephroma is a rare congenital tumor that can also manifest with an abdominal mass. About 90% of these tumors occur within the first year of life, making it an unlikely finding in a 2-year-old. Additionally, a mesoblastic nephroma would not cause elevated urine catecholamine metabolites, nor would it explain this child's abnormal eye and foot movements.
questions.hint: This child's condition is associated with amplification and overexpression of the N-myc oncogene.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive difficulty breathing and a productive cough for the past 2 days. During the past 6 months, he has had recurrent episodes of pneumonia treated with antibiotics. He has not gained weight in this time period. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Auscultation of the lungs shows decreased breath sounds over the right lung fields. Ocular examination shows periorbital subcutaneous bleeding and bulging of both eyes. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. His leukocyte count is 16,000/mm3. An x-ray of the chest shows a right-sided opacity and a collapsed right lung. An MRI of the chest shows a heterogeneous mass in the posterior mediastinum that compresses the heart and the great vessels to the left side. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Unregulated parafollicular cell proliferation in the thyroid gland
Increased lymphoblast count in the bone marrow
Unregulated B-cell proliferation in the mediastinum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Unregulated parafollicular cell proliferation in the thyroid gland indicates medullary thyroid carcinoma, which typically occurs in patients with MEN 2A or MEN 2B syndromes. MEN 2 syndromes are also associated with pheochromocytoma, which may arise in the posterior mediastinum. However, pheochromocytoma causes hypersecretion of norepinephrine, epinephrine, and/or dopamine, which leads to episodes of sweating, tachycardia, hypertension, and headaches, typically starting between the age of 20–40 years. This constellation of symptoms is not present in this 2-year-old boy, making pheochromocytoma and an associated MEN 2 syndrome very unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Overexpression of N-myc oncogene may lead to the formation of neuroblastoma, a tumor of the sympathetic nervous system usually found in the adrenal glands or sympathetic ganglia. General symptoms of neuroblastoma include failure to thrive, weight loss, nausea, and fever, while more specific symptoms depend on the location of the tumor. In approx. 20% of cases, the tumor arises from the thoracic ganglia, and mass effects in the posterior mediastinum can lead to dyspnea, cough, and airway obstruction that predisposes to respiratory infections. At the time of diagnosis, the majority of patients with neuroblastoma already have features of metastasis to the eye orbit (e.g., proptosis, “raccoon eyes”), bones (e.g., pain), and/or the skin (subcutaneous nodules).

Overexpression of N-myc oncogene is associated with a poor prognosis.
Image Description:

3-year-old girl with orbital neuroblastoma

The periorbital region of the right eye appears swollen and shows a purplish-bluish hematoma. Proptosis of the eye and subconjunctival hemorrhage (hyposphagma) can also be seen.

These findings are typical of a periorbital ecchymoses (raccoon eye) and are here associated with the spread of neuroblastoma.

C) INCORRECT:

An increased lymphoblast count in the bone marrow should raise concern for acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL), which typically manifests in children 2–5 years of age with fatigue, fever, night sweats, pallor, headaches, visual field changes, and/or bone pain. ALL may metastasize to the mediastinum and cause lymphadenopathy but would not cause a posterior mediastinal mass. This patient's presentation is not consistent with ALL.

D) INCORRECT:

Unregulated B-cell proliferation can lead to mediastinal lymphomas (e.g., non-Hodgkin lymphoma), which may manifest with fever and failure to thrive, as well as dyspnea and cough due to airway compression. However, lymphomas are usually located in the anterior rather than the posterior mediastinum, and most patients present with nontender lymphadenopathy. Furthermore, lymphomas are rare in children < 5 years of age. This patient's posterior mediastinal mass and periorbital ecchymoses indicate a different diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

AChR antibodies are responsible for myasthenia gravis (MG). Although MG is often associated with a concurrent thymoma, this patient does not show any signs of progressive generalized muscular weakness (e.g., ptosis or diplopia due to ocular muscle weakness). A thymoma would also be located in the anterior rather than the posterior mediastinum. Moreover, neither MG nor thymoma is associated with recurrent pulmonary infections, periorbital ecchymoses, or proptosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Sputum microscopy shows acid-fast bacteria in active tuberculosis (TB). Active TB usually manifests with a persistent dry cough and B symptoms (fevers, weight loss, sweating at night) for > 3 weeks. This patient has had a productive cough for only 2 days and his chest x-ray shows a right-sided opacity, which makes TB very unlikely. A posterior mediastinal mass would also not be expected in TB.
Image Description:

Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

G) INCORRECT:

Elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels can indicate an extragonadal germ cell tumor. This tumor most commonly occurs in the mediastinum and can cause chest pain, dyspnea, and a cough. However, mediastinal extragonadal germ cell tumors typically occur in the anterior mediastinum, not the posterior mediastinum. Furthermore, a germ cell tumor would not explain this boy's ocular symptoms.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation raises concern for the most common extracranial solid tumor in children.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for a 2-week history of mild fever, irritability, and poor feeding. Examination shows an abdominal mass that can be palpated in the left upper quadrant. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a mass in the left lumbar area that extends across the midline. A 24-hour urine collection test shows elevated levels of homovanillic acid and vanillylmandelic acid. A biopsy of the abdominal mass shows clusters of small round blue cells with hyperchromatic nuclei surrounding a central pale area containing neuropil. The cells stain positive for neuron-specific enolase. Molecular analysis shows very high levels of the MYCN protein inside these cells. Which of the following genetic events is most likely responsible for the described molecular finding?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Histone deacetylation is an epigenetic modification that tightens DNA coils, thereby decreasing gene transcription. Dysregulated histone deacetylases (HDACs) can promote carcinogenesis by decreasing the transcription of cell cycle inhibitors (e.g., p21 in colorectal cancer) or cell differentiation factors (e.g., Runx1 in leukemia). In this case, the increased MYCN protein levels are due to increased gene rather than decreased gene transcription. Histone acetylation, which relaxes DNA coils, is the epigenetic modification that would increase gene transcription.

B) INCORRECT:

Loss of heterozygosity (LOH) is a genetic event in which one of a gene's two heterozygous alleles is deleted or becomes nonfunctional. If one of the alleles of a tumor suppressor gene is already dysfunctional (e.g., due to an inherited mutation), a subsequent LOH event involving the functioning complementary gene will lead to neoplastic transformation. Conditions caused by LOH include Li-Fraumeni syndrome (TP53 gene) and heritable retinoblastoma (Rb gene, two-hit hypothesis). Deletions can be detected in approx. 50% of patients with neuroblastomas (e.g., deletion of the tumor suppressor KIF1B gene on chromosome 1p). However, this patient's high levels of MYCN protein, which are coded for by an oncogene, cannot be caused by LOH.

C) CORRECT:

For in-vivo genetic alterations, gene amplification is an increase in the number of copies of one gene sequence without a proportional increase in the number of copies of other gene sequences. In approx. 25% of patients with neuroblastomas, the MYCN (N-myc) oncogene on chromosome 2p is replicated 50–100 times. These copies either remain as extrachromosomal DNA (double minutes) or can be integrated into a chromosome, and they result in overexpression of the growth-promoting transcription factor MYCN, as seen here. MYCN gene amplification indicates a poor prognosis independent of the patient's age or neuroblastoma stage. Other amplified oncogenes include genes that encode epidermal growth factor receptors, such as ERBB2 (HER2/neu) in breast and gastric cancer and ERBB1 (HER1) in colorectal cancer and lung adenocarcinoma. Medications that target the products of these amplified oncogenes (e.g., trastuzumab, erlotinib, cetuximab) are now used in cancer therapy.

The term gene amplification is also used to refer to the in-vitro amplification of genetic material during a polymerase chain reaction.

D) INCORRECT:

Splice site mutations cause retention of introns and/or loss of exons, which results in defective mRNA and altered amino acid sequence length rather than an increase in the levels of protein expression, as seen here with increased levels of MYCN protein. Examples of conditions caused by splice site mutations include Gaucher disease, Marfan syndrome, dementia, epilepsy, hematological malignancies, and certain forms of β-thalassemia.
Image Description:

Exon-intron boundaries (splice sites) are specific nucleotide sequences (GU at the 5′ end; AG at the 3′ end in this image) in a newly transcripted pre-mRNA. They are recognized by spliceosomes that excise the non-coding introns and join the coding exons together.
Introns also contain pyrimidine-rich sequences (polypyrimidine tract) at the 3′ splice site that regulate alternative splicing.

E) INCORRECT:

Loss of function mutations in tumor suppressor genes (e.g., WT1, WT2, APC, NF1, BRCA1) decrease the expression of growth-inhibiting factors and result in malignancy. A nephroblastoma, which can be caused by a loss of function of WT1 or WT2, manifests during early childhood as a mass in the lumbar region, and a biopsy can show small blue round cells (from the blastema component of a neuroblastoma). However, the nephroblastoma usually does not cross the abdominal midline, elevated catecholamine degradation products would not be expected, and tumor analysis would not show Homer-Wright rosettes, neuron-specific enolase, or high levels of MYCN, as seen here. The protein MYCN is a growth-promoting transcription factor and is produced by an oncogene rather than a tumor suppressor gene; the high levels of MYCN protein seen here are due to an alteration that results in a gain rather than a loss of function.
questions.hint: This patient has neuroblastoma, an aggressive neuroendocrine tumor that primarily affects infants. The presence of an abdominal mass that crosses the midline in combination with elevated catecholamine degradation products and biopsy findings of small round blue cells with clustering around a central pale area containing neuropil (Homer-Wright rosettes) are characteristic of this tumor.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of new bruising around both eyes that developed during the past day. His parents report that he has had 3 weeks of low-grade fevers, ranging from 37.8°C to 38.3°C, and has been increasingly fussy. They are concerned that he is in pain but cannot identify the source. They deny any trauma and are quite distressed about the bruising. Until now, their son has been a healthy, thriving infant with no hospitalizations.
On examination, the patient has a temperature of 38.5°C, a heart rate of 132 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 95/64 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while breathing ambient air. He is fussy and appears tired, with bruising under both eyes (figure). His anterior fontanelle remains patent; it is flat and not bulging. His cardiorespiratory examination is normal. His abdomen is moderately distended, full, and tender to palpation. There is a palpable intra-abdominal mass extending from the right side of his abdomen to just left of midline. Given the mass, it is difficult to assess for hepatosplenomegaly.
An abdominal MRI is ordered, as well as a complete blood count, coagulation studies, electrolyte levels, and uric acid measurement.
Which one of the following additional laboratory findings would help to solidify this patient’s diagnosis?

choices.text: Elevated serum beta human chorionic gonadotropin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic evaluation for suspected neuroblastoma includes a complete blood count, coagulation studies, liver function tests, and measurement of electrolytes, creatinine, uric acid, and lactate dehydrogenase. Although these tests can suggest malignancy, they are not specific for neuroblastoma. Formal diagnosis requires either pathologic confirmation from tumor tissue or pathologic confirmation from a bone-marrow sample. More than 90% of patients with neuroblastoma also have elevated urine or serum catecholamines or catecholamine metabolites (vanillylmandelic acid, homovanillic acid, and dopamine).

B) INCORRECT:

This patient’s clinical picture is consistent with neuroblastoma, the most commonly diagnosed extracranial solid malignancy in infancy. Serum beta human chorionic gonadotropin may be elevated in association with germ-cell tumors.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient’s clinical picture is consistent with neuroblastoma, the most commonly diagnosed extracranial solid malignancy in infancy. Serum alpha-fetoprotein may be elevated in hepatocellular carcinoma, hepatoblastoma, and some malignant germ-cell tumors.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s clinical picture is consistent with neuroblastoma, the most commonly diagnosed extracranial solid malignancy in infancy.

Neuroblastoma is a malignant tumor arising from the neural crest cells of the sympathetic nervous system. The adrenal medulla and paraspinal area are the most common areas of primary disease. About two-thirds of children with neuroblastoma present with an abdominal mass, and about half present with metastatic disease, usually with systemic symptoms such as pain, fever, and malaise. Neuroblastoma frequently metastasizes to the orbits and may manifest with bilateral ecchymosis (raccoon eyes), proptosis, or both (as in this patient).

Diagnostic evaluation for suspected neuroblastoma includes a complete blood count, coagulation studies, liver function tests, and measurement of electrolytes, creatinine, uric acid, and lactate dehydrogenase. Although these tests can suggest malignancy, they are not specific for neuroblastoma. Formal diagnosis requires either pathologic confirmation from tumor tissue or pathologic confirmation from a bone-marrow sample. More than 90% of patients with neuroblastoma also have elevated urine or serum catecholamines or catecholamine metabolites (vanillylmandelic acid, homovanillic acid, and dopamine). On rare occasions, if the patient is too ill to undergo biopsy (for instance, when the patient has symptoms of spinal cord compression) and the clinical picture, imaging, and/or catecholamine levels are consistent with neuroblastoma, therapy will be initiated without pathologic diagnosis.

Although the other tests listed may be useful for other types of tumors, they are not helpful for diagnosing neuroblastoma. Serum beta human chorionic gonadotropin may be elevated in association with germ-cell tumors; serum alpha-fetoprotein may be elevated in hepatocellular carcinoma, hepatoblastoma, and some malignant germ-cell tumors; and serum cancer antigen 125 may be elevated in ovarian tumors and lymphomas.

Key learning point: In addition to imaging, the most helpful laboratory test to diagnose neuroblastoma is measurement of serum and urine catecholamines.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient’s clinical picture is consistent with neuroblastoma, the most commonly diagnosed extracranial solid malignancy in infancy. Serum cancer antigen 125 may be elevated in ovarian tumors and lymphomas.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother for evaluation of a firm abdominal bulge noticed one week ago. He has had decreased appetite and irritability for the past month. He appears pale. Examination reveals a firm mass extending across the midline in the left abdomen. No hematuria is detected, but his mother reports occasional sweating episodes. The remainder of the physical examination is normal.

Blood pressure
110/70 mm Hg

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hepatoblastoma, the most common malignant liver tumor in young children, typically presents as a right upper quadrant mass. It is often associated with elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein. The mass in this patient is located in the left abdomen and crosses the midline, which is inconsistent with a liver tumor. Additionally, the systemic symptoms suggest catecholamine secretion, not hepatic dysfunction.

B) CORRECT:

Neuroblastoma is a malignancy arising from neural crest cells, often originating in the adrenal medulla or sympathetic ganglia. It typically presents in young children with a firm, irregular abdominal mass that can cross the midline. The tumor's catecholamine production can cause systemic symptoms such as sweating, irritability, and decreased appetite. These features, along with the absence of hematuria, align with the presentation of neuroblastoma in pediatric patients.

Key learning point: Neuroblastoma in children often presents with an abdominal mass, systemic symptoms like weight loss, and hypertension due to catecholamine secretion, distinguishing it from other pediatric tumors such as Wilms tumor.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydronephrosis manifests as a fluid-filled enlargement of the renal collecting system, not a firm, solid mass. It is often accompanied by urinary symptoms like recurrent infections or hematuria. The firm mass crossing the midline and systemic symptoms such as sweating and irritability are atypical for hydronephrosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Wilms tumor, a pediatric renal malignancy, usually presents as a smooth, well-circumscribed mass confined to one side of the abdomen. It often causes hematuria and hypertension due to its renal origin. The mass in this patient crosses the midline and is associated with systemic symptoms like sweating, which are atypical for Wilms tumor.

questions.text: A previously healthy 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 10-day history of unsteady gait, frequent falls, and twitching of the extremities. Physical examination shows bilateral saccadic eye movement in all directions and brief, involuntary muscle contractions of the trunk and limbs. There is an ill-defined, nontender mass in the upper right abdomen. He undergoes surgical resection of the tumor. Histopathologic examination of this mass is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Blastic skeletal muscle cells arranged in nests and sheets
Numerous immature lymphocytes in a starry sky pattern
Abortive glomeruli and tubules in a spindle cell stroma
Small blue cells arranged in rosettes around a central neuropil
Hepatocytes in fetal and embryonic stages of differentiation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Blastic skeletal muscle cells arranged in nests and sheets are histopathologic characteristics of rhabdomyosarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma can arise from any part of the body, but the head and neck are more commonly affected than the upper abdomen, where this patient's mass was found. Moreover, this condition is not associated with opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Numerous immature lymphocytes in a starry sky pattern are histological characteristics of Burkitt lymphoma. The sporadic form of Burkitt lymphoma can manifest with an abdominal mass. However, this is a rare malignancy that typically occurs in older children. It commonly manifests with symptoms not seen in this patient, such as ascites, bowel obstruction, and gastrointestinal bleeding. Moreover, this condition is not associated with opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Abortive renal glomeruli and tubules in a spindle cell stroma are histopathologic characteristics of nephroblastoma, the most common renal malignancy in children. Nephroblastoma typically manifests with a smooth, firm, nontender abdominal mass that does not cross the midline. This condition is not associated with opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome.

D) CORRECT:

Small, blue cells arranged in rosettes around a central neuropil (Homer-Wright rosettes) are a histopathologic feature of neuroblastomas. To diagnose and monitor disease activity, urine can be tested for homovanillic acid and vanillylmandelic acid, which are produced when neuroblastoma cells metabolize catecholamines. In some cases, genetic analysis shows a deletion in chromosome 1p that amplifies the N-myc oncogene. Neuroblastomas can occur anywhere along the sympathetic chain, the majority being located in the abdomen, as seen in this patient. They become symptomatic due to the mass effect of the tumor or due to metastases (e.g., orbits, bones). This patient's opsoclonus-myoclonus ataxia is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with neuroblastoma.

Homer-Wright rosettes are also a histopathologic feature of medulloblastomas, a primary brain tumor that most commonly develops in children. Medulloblastomas are exclusively found in the cerebellum, manifesting with cerebellar dysfunction and elevated intracranial pressure.

E) INCORRECT:

Hepatocytes in fetal and embryonic stages of differentiation are histopathologic characteristics of hepatoblastoma, the most common primary hepatic malignancy in children. This malignancy typically manifests with an asymptomatic, upper right abdominal mass. However, this condition is not associated with opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient presents with gait ataxia and twitching of the eyes (opsoclonus) and extremities (myoclonus). Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome in a patient with an abdominal mass is highly suggestive of a diagnosis of neuroblastoma, the most common extracranial solid malignancy of childhood.
